dt: {bc}the gaseous envelope of a celestial body (such as a planet)
{bc}the whole mass of air surrounding the earth

dt.t: the stuffy {wi}atmosphere{/wi} of the waiting room

dt: {bc}a unit of pressure equal to the pressure of the air at sea level or approximately 14.7 pounds per square inch (101,325 {d_link|pascals|pascal})
{bc}the overall {d_link|aesthetic|aesthetic:1} effect of a work of art
{bc}an intriguing or singular tone, effect, or appeal

et: earlier in Latinate form {it}atmo-sphæra,{/it} from Greek {it}atmós{/it} "steam, vapor" (probably contracted from {it}aetmós,{/it} of uncertain origin) + {it}-o-{/it} {et_link|-o-|-o-} + Latin {it}sphaera{/it} {et_link|sphere:1|sphere:1}

The word {it}atmo-sphæra{/it} was apparently introduced by the English clergyman and natural philosopher John Wilkins (1614-72) in {it}The Discovery of a World in the Moone{/it} (London, 1638), p. 138: "Proposition 10. That there is an Atmo-sphæra, or an orbe of grosse vaporous aire, immediately encompassing the body of the Moone."
shortdef: the gaseous envelope of a celestial body (such as a planet)
the whole mass of air surrounding the earth
